metadata.title: Atlantic & Americas Shipwreck Database
metadata.description: Historic shipwrecks from Maine to Tierra del Fuego, including Caribbean, Gulf of Mexico, and Pacific South America. Focus on treasure ships with coins, jewels, and precious metals.
metadata.coverage: US East Coast, Gulf of Mexico, Caribbean, Central America, South America (Peru to Tierra del Fuego)
metadata.notes: Peru treasure route: Potosí silver → Callao port → Panama isthmus → Portobelo → Cartagena → Havana → Spain
metadata.location_notes: location_uncertainty_km indicates search radius for approximate positions. Null or 0 = precise location known.

wrecks.name: San Esteban

location.location_notes: Precise wreck site known from archaeological excavation

wrecks.cargo: 85,000+ lbs silver coins & bars from Mexican mint - worth $10M (1975)
wrecks.cargo_detail: Silver bars, silver coins (pesos), cochineal, hides
wrecks.notes: Part of 1554 fleet disaster. 'Wreck of the Three Hundred'. Survivors killed by Karankawa. Only 41% salvaged in 1554. World's oldest dated mariner's astrolabe recovered.

wrecks.name: Espíritu Santo
wrecks.notes: Sister ship to San Esteban. Found 1964. Gold bar, jewelry, navigation equipment recovered by Platoro Ltd. Texas Antiquities Code passed because of this wreck.

wrecks.name: Santa María de Yciar

location.location_notes: Destroyed by dredgers - original site approximate

wrecks.notes: Third ship of 1554 fleet. Hull split, cargo scattered. Accidentally destroyed by dredgers in late 1950s.

wrecks.name: La Girona

location.description: Lacada Point, County Antrim, Northern Ireland
location.location_notes: Precise location known, debris field mapped

wrecks.cargo: Gold coins, silver, jewelry, gold cross of Knight of Malta
wrecks.cargo_detail: Treasure from three Armada ships combined aboard
wrecks.notes: Spanish Armada galleass. Only 9 survivors from 1,300. Treasure recovered 1967-68 by Robert Sténuit. Ulster Museum Belfast exhibits.

wrecks.name: Nuestra Señora de Atocha

location.location_notes: Precisely located, debris trail extends 9 miles

wrecks.cargo_detail: Gold bars, silver bars, silver coins, emeralds, indigo, tobacco, copper
wrecks.notes: Famous treasure recovered by Mel Fisher 1985 after 16 years searching. 'Today's the Day' every morning. Sterncastle still missing. Museum in Key West.

wrecks.name: Santa Margarita
wrecks.notes: Sister ship to Atocha. Recovered by Mel Fisher 1980.

wrecks.name: Nuestra Señora del Juncal

location.description: Gulf of Mexico, between Campeche and Veracruz - NEVER FOUND
location.location_notes: NEVER FOUND. Historical records suggest sinking in hurricane between Campeche Bank and Veracruz. Search area spans 100+ nautical miles.

wrecks.cargo: 3.6 MILLION PESOS in silver/gold + 135,000 lbs cochineal + Chinese silk
wrecks.cargo_detail: Silver bars, silver coins (8 reales), gold, cochineal dye, Chinese silk, porcelain
wrecks.notes: NEVER FOUND! Flagship of 1631 New Spain fleet. Most valuable unfound Spanish treasure ship after San José. Spain & Mexico jointly searching. Contemporary accounts place loss ~50 leagues from Veracruz.

wrecks.name: Nuestra Señora de la Concepción

location.description: Silver Shoals, north of Dominican Republic
location.location_notes: General area known, debris scattered across reef system

wrecks.cargo_detail: Silver bars and coins from Peru via Panama
wrecks.notes: William Phips salvaged 1687 for English Crown. Silver Shoals named for this wreck. Peruvian silver route via Callao.

wrecks.name: Nuestra Señora de las Maravillas

location.location_notes: Primary site known, debris field extends several km

wrecks.cargo: Gold, silver, emeralds - 3.5 million items recovered over centuries
wrecks.cargo_detail: Massive treasure from Peru and Mexico
wrecks.notes: One of richest wrecks ever. Allen Exploration ongoing since 2020. Treasure recovered 1650s-1990s. Bahamas Maritime Museum exhibits.

wrecks.name: Nuestra Señora de Encarnación
wrecks.cargo_detail: Swords, nails, cloth, horseshoes, ceramics, Peruvian silver
wrecks.notes: Discovered 2011 by Texas State University. Remarkably intact. Part of Tierra Firme fleet carrying Peruvian treasure. Built in Veracruz.

wrecks.name: Nuestra Señora de la Soledad

location.description: Punta de Brujas, near Chagres River, Panama
location.location_notes: Approximate location based on historical accounts, exact site not confirmed

wrecks.cause: Storm - struck rocks and broke apart
wrecks.notes: Same Tierra Firme fleet as Encarnación. Captain Antonio de Lima drowned. All treasure lost. Exact wreck site not definitively located.

wrecks.name: San José

location.description: Off Barú Island, near Cartagena, Colombia
location.location_notes: Located by Colombia 2015, precise coordinates classified due to legal disputes

wrecks.cargo_detail: Peruvian silver and gold, Colombian emeralds, Chinese porcelain
wrecks.notes: Called 'Holy Grail of shipwrecks'. Located by Colombia 2015 using AUV. Legal disputes between Colombia, Spain, US company Sea Search Armada, Bolivia (claims Potosí silver). Largest treasure still underwater.

wrecks.name: 1715 Spanish Treasure Fleet

location.description: Florida Treasure Coast (Ft Pierce to Sebastian)
location.location_notes: Fleet scattered along 50+ mile stretch of coast. Individual wreck sites known but treasure still washing ashore.

wrecks.cargo_detail: Mexican and Peruvian silver, gold coins, jewelry, Chinese porcelain
wrecks.notes: STILL YIELDING FINDS! Coins wash up on beaches after storms. 2015: $4.5M gold chain find. Licensed salvage ongoing. Queens Jewels Fleet Inc holds salvage rights.

wrecks.name: Whydah Gally
wrecks.cargo: Pirate treasure, gold coins, African jewelry, ivory
wrecks.cargo_detail: Plundered from 50+ ships. Originally a slave ship.
wrecks.notes: ONLY authenticated Golden Age pirate shipwreck. Discovered 1984 by Barry Clifford. Ship's bell proved identity. Whydah Pirate Museum in Provincetown.

wrecks.name: Queen Anne's Revenge

location.location_notes: Precisely located, NC state archaeological site

wrecks.cargo: Pirate loot, 30+ cannons, gold dust, weapons
wrecks.notes: Blackbeard's flagship. Discovered 1996. 300,000+ artifacts recovered. French slave ship La Concorde before capture.

wrecks.name: 1733 Spanish Treasure Fleet

location.location_notes: Fleet scattered along 80 miles of Keys. Multiple individual sites known.

wrecks.cargo: Silver coins, gold coins from Mexico/Peru
wrecks.cargo_detail: Capitana (El Rubi) was flagship, grounded near Upper Matecumbe Key
wrecks.notes: Florida Underwater Archaeological Preserves. Capitana found 1938, gold recovered 2015. San Pedro and Urca de Lima are protected dive sites.

wrecks.name: El Cazador

location.description: Gulf of Mexico, 50 miles south of New Orleans
location.location_notes: Precisely located by trawler net snag 1993

wrecks.cause: Unknown (lost at sea en route to New Orleans)
wrecks.cargo_detail: Silver coins minted in Mexico, mostly 8 reales 'Pieces of Eight'
wrecks.notes: Discovered 1993 by trawler 'Mistake'. Franklin Mint bought 360,000 coins in 2007. Was bringing hard currency to stabilize Louisiana Territory economy. Loss contributed to Spain selling Louisiana to France.

wrecks.name: Nuestra Señora de las Mercedes
wrecks.cargo: 500,000 silver and gold coins (14.5 tons recovered)
wrecks.cargo_detail: Silver coins from Peru, gold, vicuña wool, cinnamon, quinoa
wrecks.notes: Odyssey Marine 'Black Swan Project'. Spain won lawsuit, coins returned 2012. Now in Cartagena Naval Museum. Peru also claimed cargo (denied).

wrecks.name: SS Central America
wrecks.cargo: 21 tons California Gold Rush gold - $150M+ recovered
wrecks.cargo_detail: Gold bars, gold coins, gold dust from California
wrecks.notes: 'Ship of Gold'. Triggered Panic of 1857. Tommy Thompson found it 1988, then became fugitive for hiding treasure. More recoveries ongoing.

wrecks.name: RMS Titanic

location.description: North Atlantic, 370 miles SE of Newfoundland
location.location_notes: Precisely mapped, bow and stern separate

wrecks.notes: Most famous shipwreck in history. Discovered 1985 by Robert Ballard. UNESCO protected site. Ship deteriorating rapidly.

wrecks.name: SS Andrea Doria
wrecks.cause: Collision with MS Stockholm in fog
wrecks.notes: Called 'Mount Everest of diving' due to difficulty. Many divers have died exploring. Collapsing rapidly.

wrecks.name: USS Monitor
wrecks.cause: Foundered in storm while under tow
wrecks.notes: Revolutionary ironclad from Battle of Hampton Roads. Turret and engine recovered. Monitor NMS protects site.

wrecks.name: RMS Rhone
wrecks.notes: Popular dive site. Featured in film 'The Deep'. BVI National Park wreck.

wrecks.name: Independencia
wrecks.cause: Battle of Punta Gruesa (War of the Pacific)
wrecks.notes: War of the Pacific. Peru vs Chile. Ran aground chasing Covadonga.

wrecks.name: Esmeralda
wrecks.notes: Battle of Iquique. Captain Arturo Prat died boarding Huáscar - Chilean national hero.

wrecks.name: Príncipe de Asturias
wrecks.notes: 'Brazilian Titanic'. Deadliest Brazilian maritime disaster.

wrecks.name: SMS Dresden
wrecks.notes: Only German cruiser to escape Battle of Falklands. Popular dive site.

wrecks.name: ARA General Belgrano

location.description: South Atlantic, south of Falkland Islands

wrecks.notes: Falklands War. Former USS Phoenix (survived Pearl Harbor). Most controversial sinking of the war.

wrecks.name: USS Maine (ACR-1)

location.location_notes: Site marked, hull raised 1912 and scuttled at sea

wrecks.notes: 'Remember the Maine!' - triggered Spanish-American War. Raised 1912 and scuttled at sea.

wrecks.name: RMS Empress of Ireland

location.description: St. Lawrence River, near Rimouski, Quebec

wrecks.cause: Collision with SS Storstad in fog
wrecks.notes: Worst Canadian maritime disaster. Sank in 14 minutes. Protected dive site.

wrecks.name: RMS Lusitania

location.description: Off Old Head of Kinsale, Ireland

wrecks.notes: Sinking helped bring US into WWI. Irish waters.
